thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: Aust bonds mixed on US inflation data
thread.title_full: Aust bonds mixed on US inflation data

title: Aust bonds mixed on US inflation data
text:
Mon, Aug 31, 2015, 9:22 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 38 mins. Aust bonds mixed on US inflation data AAP â€“ 40 minutes ago Print 
The Australian bond market is mixed, after US inflation figures met market expectations. 
US consumer spending rose slightly in July as incomes continued to grow at a steady pace, while underlying inflation remained tame. 
Consumer spending, which drives about 70 per cent of activity in the world's largest economy, rose 0.3 per cent, following an upwardly revised 0.3 per cent gain in June. 
"It didn't cause too much movement," Commonwealth Bank of Australia fixed income quantitative strategist Philip Brown said. 
Mr Brown said the local data calendar was heavy in the week ahead. 
"GDP (gross domestic product) data will provide more information on where the economy actually is, particularly when the labour force has been a bit up and down and it's hard to get a proper read," he said. 
"That will be more telling data, and, of course, everyone will be watching China as well." 
Shanghai ended the week 4.8 per cent firmer on Friday following a tumultuous week of heavy share losses. 
At 0830 AEST on Monday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.245 (implying a yield of 2.755 per cent), up from 97.235 (2.765 per cent) on Friday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.160 (1.840 per cent), down from 98.170 (1.830 per cent). 
KEY MOVEMENTS: 
* CGS 5.5pct Jan 2018, 1.798pct, from 1.798pct on Friday 
* CGS 4.25pct April 2026, 2.804pct, from 2.804pct 
Sydney Futures Exchange prices: 
* September 2015 bill futures, 97.890, from 97.900 
* December 2015 bill futures, 98.020, from 98.040 
(*Closes taken at 1630 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
